selected_quotes: Positive selection on European hair, eye, and skin alleles in the past 5000 years
...strong selection has been operating on pigmentation-related genes within western Eurasia for the past 5,000 y
Our paper on the evolution of pigmentation in Europeans came out this week, see

citation.abstract: Pigmentation is a polygenic trait encompassing some of the most visible phenotypic variation observed in humans. Here we present direct estimates of selection acting on functional alleles in three key genes known to be involved in human pigmentation pathways--HERC2, SLC45A2, and TYR--using allele frequency estimates from Eneolithic, Bronze Age, and modern Eastern European samples and forward simulations. Neutrality was overwhelmingly rejected for all alleles studied, with point estimates of selection ranging from around 2-10% per generation. Our results provide direct evidence that strong selection favoring lighter skin, hair, and eye pigmentation has been operating in European populations over the last 5,000 y.
citation.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
citation.title: Direct evidence for positive selection of skin, hair, and eye pigmentation in Europeans during the last 5,000 y

wikipedia.title: Corded Ware culture
wikipedia.summary: The culture is reflected primarily by its burials, which consisted of inhumation under tumuli with various artifacts (notably battle axes).

wikipedia.title: Haplogroup T (mtDNA)
wikipedia.summary: Haplogroup T is a human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) haplogroup. It is believed to have originated around 25,000 years ago in the Near East.

wikipedia.title: Blond
wikipedia.summary: Blond (male), blonde (female), or fair hair, is a hair color characterized by low levels of the dark pigment eumelanin.

wikipedia.title: Yamna culture
wikipedia.summary: The Yamna or Yamnaya culture, also called Pit Grave Culture and Ochre Grave Culture, was a late Copper Age/early Bronze Age culture of the Southern Bug/Dniester/Ural region (the Pontic steppe), dating to 3,500 – 2,300 BCE.
